Award.AwardTitle: NSF Support for the 2013 USENIX Security Symposium, Financial Aid; August 2013; Washington DC

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: This proposal provide funding to assist approximately 20 US-based graduate students to attend the 2013 USENIX Security Symposium, a leading forum for advanced professionals from academic and industrial backgrounds to meet and discuss the newest advances in the security of computer systems and networks. Participation in USENIX Security'13 and similar conferences is a valuable and important part of the graduate school experience. It provides students with the opportunity to interact with more senior researchers in the field, and exposes students to leading work in the field. The support provided by this grant will enable the participation of students who would otherwise be unable to attend the conference. USENIX Security'13 is scheduled to occur in Washington DC from August 14-16, 2013. The conference consists of a three-day technical program, with numerous workshops co-located. Overall, the venue provides an outstanding opportunity for students to interact with leaders in their immediate field of study.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 22nd USENIX Security Symposium (SEC'13) was held in Washington, D.C., August 14-16, 2013. USENIX Security Symposium  is the premier forum for discussing security and privacy issues. The goal of the symposium is to bring together researchers, practitioners, system administrators, system programmers, and others interested in the latest advances in the security of computer systems and networks.

The 2013 program included 45 technical papers carefully selected out of 277 submissions. The high-quality papers presented new research in a variety of subject areas, including detection of network attacks, privacy, mobile security, Internet security, and Web security.  USENIX received 80 stipend applications from students, and 44 were awarded grants. 13 stipends were covered by funds received under this award. Selections were made based on a number of factors, and preference was given to students who were (i) first-time applicants, (ii) willing to volunteer at the conference,  (iii) their area of study significantly overlapped with the conference topic (as demonstrated by a concise supporting statement outlining their research) (iv) at institutions not traditionally represented at USENIX events, (v) at different levels of study and (vi) able to demonstrate a financial need.

For those students selected, USENIX covered the registration costs by providing students with a complimentary registration and expensed portion of their airfare and accomodation costs. All students granted stipends attend US-based schools, which included: Arizona State University, Rice University, North Carolina State University, Lehigh University, Pennsylvania State University, University of Michigan, Stevens Institute of Technology, Texas A&M University, University of California at Irvine, University of Virginia, University of California at San Deigo, University of Illinois at Chicago, University of California at Santa Barbara. The financial support of the NSF allowed USENIX to grant awards to many more qualified applicants than would have been possible otherwise. There were 663 total attendees the week of SEC ’13 and 516 attendees specifically at the main symposium. Non-US attendees came from 29 different countries.
